Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Small-Dose Intravenous Ketamine with Continuous Femoral Nerve Block in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty were randomly assigned to receive either an initial bolus of 0.5 mg/kg ketamine followed by a continuous infusion of 3 μg·kg -1 ·min -1 during surgery and 1.5 μg·kg -1 ·min -1 for 48 h (Ketamine group) or an equal volume of saline (Control group).

Intervention.evidence: patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty were randomly assigned to receive either an initial bolus of 0.5 mg/kg ketamine followed by a continuous infusion of 3 μg·kg -1 ·min -1 during surgery and 1.5 μg·kg -1 ·min -1 for 48 h (Ketamine group) or an equal volume of saline (Control group).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the effect of small-dose intravenous ketamine combined with continuous femoral nerve block on postoperative pain and rehabilitation after total knee arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was morphine consumption over 48 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the Ketamine group and 100 to the Control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The Ketamine group required significantly less morphine than the Control group (45 ± 20 mg versus 69 ± 30 mg; P < 0.02).
